CatDescriptText: Miss Donna Connors, student, McKees Rocks, Mr. Gary Miller, student, McKees Rocks, and Mr. George Nicholson, steelworker, Lawrenceville, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column, published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 5, 1962, pg. 6 with question: "Do you think Southerners are sincere in wanting to send Negroes without jobs to the North on Freedom Trains?"  Miss Donna Connors' answer reads: "They are probably sincere, I think they are trying to send these people away...trying to get rid of the problem.  And the problem is not being solved but just shifted to the North where we have a lot of unemployment.  This may bring out the prejudices within people which previously was only to a small degree.  Mr. Gary Miler's answer reads: "...They should try to solve their own problems there instead of shifting it to the North where we seemingly have no outward problem."  Mr. George Nicholson's answer reads: "No, I don't think they are sincere..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Group portrait of Donna Connors wearing paisley blouse and Gary Miller wearing eyeglasses, standing in front of Bud Saunders flower shop, Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of George Nicholson wearing hat, sunglasses, and double breasted pinstriped jacket, standing in front of Bud Saunders flower shop, Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
